description:
The '''New Mexico music''' genre ({{langx|es|link=no|música nuevo mexicana}}) is a genre of music that originated in the US state of [[New Mexico]]. It derives from [[Puebloan peoples|Pueblo]] [[Pueblo music|music]] in the 13th century, and with the [[folk music]] of [[Hispanos of New Mexico|Hispanos]] during the 16th to 19th centuries in [[Santa Fe de Nuevo México]].

During the early 1900s, the genre began to incorporate [[country music]] and [[American folk music]]. The 1950s and 1960s brought the influences of [[blues]], jazz, [[rockabilly]], and [[rock and roll]] into New Mexico music. During the 1970s, the music style entered [[popular music]] in the Southwestern United States.

The language of the vocals in New Mexico music is usually [[Mexican Spanish|Mexican]] and [[New Mexican Spanish]], [[American English|American]] and [[New Mexican English]], [[Spanglish]], [[Tiwa languages|Tiwa]], [[Hopi language|Hopi]], [[Zuni language|Zuni]], [[Navajo language|Navajo]], and/or [[Southern Athabaskan languages]].
